content: Would anyone be interested in a topic about the history of PSSL?

Rongmin Lu said:

Would anyone be interested in a topic about the history of PSSL?

I would. :-)

sarahzrf said:

PSSL?

It's the Peripatetic Seminar on Sheaves and Logic. The historical record, alas, is also a little peripatetic. :sweat_smile:

Valeria de Paiva mentioned in Joachim Kock's AMA that she once had to accommodate Anders Kock at her place for a PSSL because the accommodation arrangements were messed up for some reason. I had the same question as you, and went to look for the answer.

Here's what I found and posted:

For the uninitiated: PSSL is the Peripatetic Seminar on Sheaves and Logic, which "grew out of Dana Scott's seminars for his research students at Oxford."

For historical interest: Gavin Wraith maintains a list of PSSLs up until the 70th (1976-99), while Valeria has a list covering PSSL 71-94. The most recent PSSL would have been the 106th at Leeds if not for COVID-19.
It's actually a pretty famous seminar series, so I'm hoping we could hear some interesting stories.
I actually gave a talk at the last one (the 105th), held in Palermo last year. The 106th was supposed to be in Leeds this April. Maybe it will eventually happen..!

Morgan Rogers said:

I actually gave a talk at the last one (the 105th), held in Palermo last year. The 106th was supposed to be in Leeds this April. Maybe it will eventually happen..!

so ok, we got the websites for PSSL 105 https://sites.google.com/view/pssl-105, and PSSL 104 https://mysite.science.uottawa.ca/phofstra/PSSL18.html. Looks like we're out of luck with PSSL 103. Google only found "Masaryk University will host the 103rd edition of PSSL. We look forward to see you in Brno! all the relevant informations are on the conference website." but he conference website gives me a 404. I had more luck with PSSL 102, https://www.usc.es/regaca/pssl102/ Finally we get http://www1.maths.leeds.ac.uk/~pmtng/PSSL/pssl101.html.
